coordinator module

coordinator.main(input_dir, is_dry)[source]

deployment_generator module

deployment_generator.check_match_combined_used_resources(combined_resources, used_resources)[source]
deployment_generator.get_deployments()[source]

From the testing units, generates all the possible combinations of them; these are the possible deployments.

Returns:

None

deployment_generator.get_resources_combinations(resources)[source]
deployment_generator.get_services_to_test()[source]

Returns a list of services to test given the current deployment, skipping the ones already tested in previous deployments, and adding in the alternative versions, if any.

Returns:

list of services (Service class)

deployment_generator.get_testing_units()[source]

This function lists all the available containers, divided in groups, BUT partitions are grouped together. Component_groups contains a list for each group (component1, component2, …), and each list contains all the testing_units for that group; a testing_unit is just a way to keep together all the correlated partitions. An example of testing unit for a base component is [‘C1@VM1’], an example for a partitioned component is [‘C1P1.1@VM1’, ‘C1P1.2@VM1’]

Returns:

container_groups, list of lists

deployment_generator.has_completes_results(deployment_dir, service_dir)[source]
deployment_generator.make_deployments_summary()[source]

Prints the list of the deployments, and also writes it to a file.

Returns:

None

deployment_generator.make_resources_requirements()[source]

Calculates the requirements of each resource in terms of nodes, given the hardware of the resource, the requirements of the containers, and the number of parallel instances to be supported. The calculations are done taking into account a 10% headroom for the OS in terms of both CPU and RAM.

Returns:

None

deployment_generator.reorder_deployments(deployments, resources)[source]

infrastructure_manager module

infrastructure_manager._generate_modified_candidate_files(to_deploy)[source]

Generate a modified version of candidate_deployments, containing (only) the components that are needed for the current test; this file is needed by the Toscarizer to generate the correct TOSCA files. Additionally, it returns the names of the components that need to be deployed.

infrastructure_manager._generate_modified_dag()[source]

Similar to the previous function, it creates a customized version of the application_dag containing whatever needs to be tested; the file is used by the Toscarizer.

infrastructure_manager.adjust_physical_infrastructures_configuration()[source]
infrastructure_manager.clean_and_rename_tosca(tosca_file, component_name, resource, node_requirements)[source]

This function “cleans” the Tosca file by removing the section related to OSCAR and its services, since those will be deployed by OSCAR-P instead. It also selects the correct number of nodes, sets the domain name, and renames the file as its associated resource (e.g. VM1.yaml).

infrastructure_manager.clean_and_rename_tosca_files(to_deploy, tosca_files)[source]

Calls clean_and_rename_tosca() for each tosca_files.

infrastructure_manager.configure_executables()[source]

This function configures the executables (MC and oscar_cli) used by OSCAR-P according to the credentials retrieved from IM.

infrastructure_manager.configure_jmeter_cluster()[source]
infrastructure_manager.create_virtual_infrastructures()[source]

Scenario 1: starting from zero, assumes “virtual_infrastructures.json” not present, or present but the infrastructures no longer exist on IM; in both cases, reset virtual_infrastructures as {}, then delete all on IM with delete_unused_virtual_infrastructures. Scenario 2: resuming interrupted, checks that “virtual_infrastructures.json” is present and its infrastructures are still on IM: if yes, delete_unused_virtual_infrastructures anyway, nothing bad should happen, if not, proceed as for scenario 1. Scenario 3: changing deployment, “virtual_infrastructures.json” will be loaded but it won’t change anything, proceed as usual.

infrastructure_manager.delete_all_virtual_infrastructures()[source]

This function deletes ALL virtual infrastructures, without checks.

infrastructure_manager.delete_unused_virtual_infrastructures()[source]

This function deletes unused virtual infrastructures; first it checks if there are infrastructures deployed on IM but not tracked by gp.virtual_infrastructures, then checks if there are non-existing infrastructures still tracked in gp.virtual_infrastructures, and finally checks if there are deployed and tracked infrastructures that are no longer needed.

infrastructure_manager.delete_virtual_infrastructure(inf_url)[source]

This function deletes a virtual infrastructure.

infrastructure_manager.deploy_virtual_infrastructure(tosca_file, resource, inf_id)[source]

This function calls the IM API to deploy (or update) all the virtual infrastructure.

infrastructure_manager.generate_tosca()[source]

Given the original of modified files, this function uses the Toscarizer to generate the required Tosca files.

infrastructure_manager.get_all_infrastructures()[source]

This function returns a list of all infrastructures deployed on IM.

infrastructure_manager.get_infrastructures_outputs()[source]

This function retrieves the outputs (endpoints and credentials) from IM for every virtual resource and stores them in the virtual_infrastructures.json file.

infrastructure_manager.get_node_list(client)[source]
infrastructure_manager.get_outputs(inf_url)[source]

This function retrieves the outputs (endpoints and credentials) from IM for a single virtual resource.

infrastructure_manager.get_state(inf_url)[source]

This function returns the state of the deployment of a virtual infrastructure.

infrastructure_manager.update_tosca(tosca_file, resource, node_requirements, current_base_run_index)[source]

This function updates the Tosca file of a virtual infrastructure by setting the correct number of nodes.

infrastructure_manager.update_virtual_infrastructures()[source]

This function updates the virtual infrastructures, usually by reducing its nodes.

infrastructure_manager.wait_for_infrastructure_deployment(is_update=False)[source]

This function waits for the deployment of the virtual infrastructure, checking on their status periodically. If an error is detected, the execution stops.

input_files_parser module

input_files_parser._check_device_constraints(base_component_name, memory_size, gpu_requirement)[source]

Ensures that the memory and GPU constraints between the annotations.yaml and the candidate_deployments.yaml are consistent.

input_files_parser._get_actual_partitions(component_key)[source]

This function returns an array containing the partition groups that match the component name, which is needed to turn “partitionX_1” into “partition1_1”. The candidate_deployments.yaml file has no knowledge about the actual generated partitions, so we need to get this information from the component_partitions.yaml file.

input_files_parser._get_bucket_name_for_lambda(resource_name)[source]

Reads the name of the bucket of the AWS resource from the physical_nodes.yaml file.

Parameters:

resource_name (str) – name of the AWS resource

Returns:

None

input_files_parser._get_physical_nodes()[source]

Parses the physical_nodes.yaml file and extracts the info related to the SSH front node access, so IP, port and user.

Returns:

dictionary with the parsed information

input_files_parser._set_containers(parent_component, component_key, containers)[source]

Given a component, it adds a Container class to it for each of the containers listed under that component in candidate_deployments.yaml.

Parameters:

  • parent_component (Component) – component to add containers to

  • component_key (str) – component key (e.g. component1)

  • containers (dict) – containers dictionary as extracted from candidate_deployments.yaml

Returns:

None

input_files_parser.check_parallelism_is_in_decreasing_order(parallelism)[source]

Ensures that the parallelism array is listed in decreasing order, if not it interrupts the execution and shows an error. If the parallelism is listed in increasing order, the testing takes more time because the VMs need to be created as needed, and that takes 15 minutes.

Parameters:

parallelism (list) – parallelism array

Returns:

None

input_files_parser.get_components()[source]

TLDR: get all the components and their docker images from candidate_deployments.yaml. This functions reads the components from candidate_deployments.yaml, saves them in Component objects, and then saves them as dictionary indexed by group and by name. As an example, components_groups is organized as follows: [ component1 -> blurry-faces-onnx -> blurry-faces-onnx.containers -> C1@VM1 -> image: blurry-faces-onnx_base_amd641_amd64:latest ]. Basically it’s groups -> ACTUAL components -> containers -> appropriate (single) docker image. Component_names instead skips a step and indexes them directly by name (e.g. blurry-faces-onnx, blurry-faces-onnx_partition1_1, …) Finally, containers is a dictionary indexed by unit (e.g. C1@VM2, C1PX.1@VM2, …).

input_files_parser.get_resources()[source]

Reads the resources from the candidate_resources.yaml file and reorganizes them as Resource classes.

Returns:

None

input_files_parser.get_run_parameters()[source]

Reads the run_parameters.yaml file and sets the run_parameters and component_parallelism global variables. Additionally it makes sure that the parallelism lists are of the same length and in decreasing order.

input_files_parser.set_testing_parameters()[source]

Adds the parallelism field and the time distribution (the latter needed for single service testing) to the Component classes.

Returns:

None

input_files_parser.shorten_key(component_key)[source]

Receives a component key and returns a shortened version (e.g. component1 -> C1, component1_partitionX_1 -> C1P1.1).

Parameters:

component_key (str) – component key

Returns:

shortened component key
